answers.answer: Hi,have you considered delivering without epidural.  It is possible?Do you have an option for a water birth.  I have read that it is very helpful if there are back issues.Read up so you know your options.7.5 lbs is not so big for a baby that is due any time in the next 4 weeks.

I'm sure the doc will make sure they do the epi so that it's not gonna hurt ur back anymore. It's probably ur sciatic nerve that's causing the pain n numbness dwn ur back. I'm havn that same pain. Doc said a chiropractor would help me a lot I also have 2 bulge discs n my back so I know what it is ur goin thru. Baby weight is good at this point don't worry bout him being to big he's average weight right now. I'm not sure how u handle pain but try not to get epi like the other person said if u can. Otherwise ur n good hands with ur docs trust them...Good luck!!!!
I would look into a chiropractor

My.dr is making a really big deal about the baby's wieght.  I thought he must be huge or.something.  im not a fan of pain and my back is already so bad that natural child birth really scares me.  What else is there other than cesarean.

I had natural birth with both my kids and believe metthat's the best way and epidural can have side effect of back pain with some people and you said you already have bad abck so I will say go for oth options morphine may be if you want xxx
FWIW, I was told my baby was weighing close to 9lbs at 38w. She was 6lbs 1oz when she was born via c-s (breech) a week later!

You'll be fine. The dr will make sure the epi is done correctly. Make sure when U check into the hospital once in labor they know your concerns. Talk to the nurses once in the delivery room. Make sure Ur delivery coach (hubby/friend/dula) knows to do the same. I'm sure Ur not the 1st person they've seen w this as an issue/concern. Try to relax. Good luck. Your baby will be in Ur arms soon.

Women with gestational diabetes do tend to have larger babies but you can't always go by the ultrasound's estimated weight. My dr said they can be more than a pound off in either direction. I was told my son was around 6 pounds, 4 days before he was born. He was nearly 9 pounds. Like a comment above, she was told 9 pounds and baby was 6. My niece was told hers was 9 pounds and she was born at 7 pounds. Don't let baby's size scare you, it doesn't necessarily mean the bigger the baby the more pain you will be in. My 7.9 pounder hurt MUCH worse than my 9 pounder.
Don't worry. Ultrasounds can be off by 2+lbs.

question: Im 38 weeks with my first (a boy). My dr says hes already 7.5 lbs (estimated) and I'm positively enormous.  Everyone keeps asking me if I'm having twins.  I am very very nervous about labor.  I have a really bad back. Three compressed vertebrates, bulging disks, and a previous injury from falling through a glass table that put glass into my spine and caused nerve damage along the same place they put an epidural in.  My dr doesn't seem concerned at all about the epidural... But do they normally put an epidural in a space with compressed vertebrates and a bulging disk?  Ive been having Braxton hicks and false labor contractions since week 26 and they are only getting stronger but every time they get bad i have bad back spasms, shooting pain down my legs, then i will go numb in mt feet and lower legs.  I told my dr and he doesn't seem concerned.  I also have gestational diabetes and low/normal blood preasure (yes..low not high).Am i panicking over nothing or is my dr ignoring my concerns when he shouldn't?
title: 38 weeks, seriously nervous!!
